geographical.features: Distinctive dome-shaped mountain rising 575 meters above sea level, approximately 450 meters above the Jezreel Valley floor

longDescription: Mount Tabor (Hebrew: Har Tavor) is a distinctive, dome-shaped mountain rising 575 meters above sea level in Lower Galilee, Israel. Since at least the 4th century CE, Christian tradition has identified this mountain as the site of Jesus Christ's Transfiguration, described in the Synoptic Gospels (Matthew 17:1-9; Mark 9:2-8; Luke 9:28-36). On this 'high mountain apart,' Jesus was transfigured before Peter, James, and John - his face shining like the sun, his garments becoming dazzling white - while Moses and Elijah appeared conversing with him about his 'exodus' (departure/death) to be accomplished in Jerusalem. The voice of the Father declared: 'This is my beloved Son; listen to him.' The mountain's isolated position, rising dramatically from the surrounding plain, made it a natural site for sacred significance long before Christianity. The Hebrew Bible mentions Tabor as a tribal boundary marker and as the gathering point for Deborah and Barak's forces before their victory over the Canaanite general Sisera. Its distinctive shape made it proverbial for greatness (Psalm 89:12; Jeremiah 46:18).
shortDescription: Traditional site of Jesus Christ's Transfiguration, where he appeared in divine glory before Peter, James, and John, conversing with Moses and Elijah. A major Christian pilgrimage destination since the 4th century.
name: Mount Tabor

transfiguration.text: After six days Jesus took with him Peter and James and John his brother, and led them up a high mountain by themselves. And he was transfigured before them, and his face shone like the sun, and his clothes became white as light.
transfiguration.significance: Primary account of the Transfiguration with emphasis on Jesus' divine glory

transfiguration.text: And he was transfigured before them, and his clothes became radiant, intensely white, as no one on earth could bleach them. And there appeared to them Elijah with Moses, and they were talking with Jesus.
transfiguration.significance: Earliest Gospel account; emphasis on whiteness beyond earthly possibility

transfiguration.text: Now about eight days after these sayings he took with him Peter and John and James and went up on the mountain to pray. And as he was praying, the appearance of his face was altered, and his clothing became dazzling white.
transfiguration.significance: Only account mentioning prayer; specifies they discussed Jesus' 'exodus' in Jerusalem

transfiguration.text: For we did not follow cleverly devised myths when we made known to you the power and coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, but we were eyewitnesses of his majesty... when we were with him on the holy mountain.
transfiguration.significance: Apostolic testimony to the historical reality of the Transfiguration

oldTestament.text: She sent and summoned Barak... 'Go, gather your men at Mount Tabor'
oldTestament.significance: Deborah's command to Barak; staging ground for victory over Sisera

oldTestament.text: The boundary touches Tabor, Shahazumah, and Beth-shemesh
oldTestament.significance: Tribal boundary marker for Issachar, Zebulun, and Naphtali

oldTestament.text: The north and the south, you have created them; Tabor and Hermon joyously praise your name
oldTestament.significance: Tabor personified as praising God; symbol of creation's grandeur

oldTestament.text: As I live, declares the King... like Tabor among the mountains and like Carmel by the sea, shall one come
oldTestament.significance: Tabor as proverbial for majesty and prominence

oldTestament.text: For you have been a snare at Mizpah and a net spread upon Tabor
oldTestament.significance: Reference to pagan worship sites; Tabor as pre-Israelite high place

transfigurationTheology.christological: The Transfiguration reveals Christ's divine glory normally veiled during his earthly ministry. The disciples see 'the kingdom of God come with power' (Mark 9:1) - a preview of resurrection glory and the eschaton.
transfigurationTheology.trinitarian: All three Persons of the Trinity are present: the Son transfigured, the Father speaking from the cloud, the Spirit present in the luminous glory (shekinah).
transfigurationTheology.salvation_history: Moses (representing the Law) and Elijah (representing the Prophets) converge on Jesus, confirming that he fulfills all Scripture. They discuss his 'exodus' - his death, resurrection, and ascension.
transfigurationTheology.theosis: In Eastern theology, the Transfiguration reveals the goal of human salvation: participation in divine glory. Gregory Palamas taught that the disciples saw the uncreated divine light, accessible to all who pursue sanctification.

patristicInterpretation.author: Origen (c. 185-254)
patristicInterpretation.teaching: The Transfiguration shows Christ's multiple 'forms' - appearing differently according to the spiritual capacity of the viewer

patristicInterpretation.author: John Chrysostom (347-407)
patristicInterpretation.teaching: Christ showed a glimpse of his divine glory to strengthen the disciples for the scandal of the cross

patristicInterpretation.author: Anastasius of Sinai (d. 700)
patristicInterpretation.teaching: The mountain itself was transfigured, becoming an icon of paradise

patristicInterpretation.author: Gregory Palamas (1296-1359)
patristicInterpretation.teaching: The light of Tabor was the uncreated divine energy, the same light that will illumine the saints in the age to come

dates.western: August 6 (added to Roman calendar 1457 by Pope Callixtus III)

liturgicalCelebration.significance: Celebrates the revelation of Christ's divine glory; in the East, associated with blessing of grapes and first fruits
liturgicalCelebration.hymns: Byzantine kontakion: 'You were transfigured on the mountain, O Christ God, revealing your glory to your disciples'

sacredSignificance: Mount Tabor holds profound significance as the traditional site of Christ's Transfiguration - the moment when Jesus' divine glory was revealed to Peter, James, and John. This event, positioned between his ministry and passion, confirmed Jesus' identity as the divine Son and foreshadowed the resurrection. The Transfiguration is celebrated as a major feast in both Eastern and Western Christianity, and the mountain has been a pilgrimage destination since the early Church.

description: Mount Tabor, the traditional site of Christ's Transfiguration, is a dome-shaped mountain in Lower Galilee where Jesus revealed his divine glory to Peter, James, and John. The current Church of the Transfiguration (1924) crowns the summit, built over Byzantine and Crusader remains.
significance: Traditional site of Jesus Christ's Transfiguration, where he appeared in divine glory before Peter, James, and John, conversing with Moses and Elijah. Mount Tabor has been a place of Christian pilgrimage since at least the 4th century CE. The event reveals Christ's divine nature, confirms the witness of the Law and Prophets, and foreshadows resurrection glory.

pilgrimageHistory.earlyChristian: By the 4th century, Mount Tabor was firmly identified as the Transfiguration site. Cyril of Jerusalem (c. 350) mentioned the tradition. The pilgrim Egeria (381-384) and the anonymous Piacenza Pilgrim (570) described churches on the summit.
pilgrimageHistory.byzantinePeriod: Three churches were built on the summit in the 6th century, commemorating the three 'tabernacles' Peter offered to build. Byzantine pilgrims would ascend the mountain, celebrate liturgy, and seek spiritual renewal in the place of Christ's revealed glory.
pilgrimageHistory.crusaderPeriod: Benedictine monks established a monastery (1099). After the Battle of Hattin (1187), Saladin fortified the summit. The fortress was later dismantled. Crusader ruins remain visible today.
pilgrimageHistory.modernPeriod: The Franciscan Basilica of the Transfiguration (1924), designed by Antonio Barluzzi, crowns the summit. The Greek Orthodox Church of Elijah maintains Orthodox presence. Pilgrims visit year-round, especially on the Feast of the Transfiguration (August 6).

sacredSites.basilicaOfTransfiguration: The Franciscan basilica (1924) features stunning mosaics of the Transfiguration scene. The design incorporates two side chapels dedicated to Moses and Elijah, recalling the three tabernacles Peter proposed. Beneath lie remains of Byzantine and Crusader churches.
sacredSites.churchOfElijah: The Greek Orthodox church (19th century) serves Eastern Christian pilgrims. Its location near the summit maintains the ancient Orthodox tradition of veneration.
sacredSites.grottoes: Various caves and grottoes are venerated as places of prayer, including the traditional spot of the disciples' sleep during Christ's prayer.
sacredSites.viewpoints: The summit offers commanding views of the Jezreel Valley, Mount Hermon, and the Sea of Galilee - a panorama connecting numerous biblical sites.

comparativeNotes.christian: Mount Tabor represents a pivotal moment in salvation history: the revelation of Christ's divine glory. Unlike Sinai, where God's glory was terrifying and unapproachable, Tabor reveals glory in the person of Jesus - the God who becomes one with humanity. The presence of Moses and Elijah confirms that Jesus fulfills the Law and Prophets, while their conversation about his 'exodus' connects the Transfiguration to the cross and resurrection. For Eastern Christians, Tabor has particular theological significance: the uncreated light that shone from Christ is the same divine energy available to those who pursue holiness, making Tabor a vision of human destiny - transformation into God's likeness.
comparativeNotes.sinaiConnection: The Transfiguration deliberately echoes Sinai: both mountains, overshadowing cloud, divine voice, Moses present, divine glory revealed. But the Transfiguration transcends Sinai: the glory is not on a mountain but in a Person; the voice says not 'obey the law' but 'listen to him'; Moses is not the mediator but a witness. Where Israel could not look on Moses' glorified face, the disciples see Christ's unveiled glory and are invited into it.
